author: mskamelot
body:
I expect the gap drop 2morrow morning,

probably will sell SPY 240p 3/20 I picked up on EOD today.

if huge drop, then also will consider to dump SPY 220p 4/17 that I picked up at the same time with weekly play. Should be very nice profit with even higher IV.

My other puts 4/17 & 5/17 are deep in the money,. so I will br riding those for another 2 week or less. possibly longer. Pace of drop is very fast, so not sure when bear will hit the wall and die. but my autism guess is saying at least 2 weeks or more out.

Forgot to add RIP my TSLA 1000C Jan2021 LEAP. bought when TSLA hit 900+.

not gonna sell this call. already 90% loss on this fucker.

3mo T-yield is kind of fucked up. must be something going on with this;

author: aidv
body:
30. Male. Not fat. Quit smoking a few years back, picked it up last summer and quit again 4 months ago.

Yes. I’m in Sweden, but I don’t take Swedish health care seriously anymore. It’s good, but they’ll br overloded if more people get critically ill by this disease.

author: thomasol

author: ElephantSquad
body: The CoD BR game has 400k viewers on Twitch right now which is more than double the next game. If these were better market conditions I'd say get ATVI calls. Looks similar to EA's Apex launch.

author: Working_onit
body:
That's debatable.  This will not br nearly as bad as 2008 IMO.  Businesses are structurally more stable and the system was healthy coming into this.  Plus we got a lot more stimulus and it's very directed at all the groups affected by this downturn.

Many downturns don't send the market down 50%.  That's not an analysis at that point, it's just an opinion.  I think it's entirely possible we've already seen the bottom.  That doesn't mean the recovery will be V-shaped, but it's entirely possible the best buying opportunity is behind us.

author: cdang25
body:
Yes...look for better rates and more importantly, buy a house you can afford.  Also think about cost of utilities (is well insulated, is an old house or new house) you can get the costs for the year from the seller, real estate agent or the utility company. also the cost of taxes, yard maintenance.  I think the housing market is relative as far as going up or down. I feel the pricing of the house will be more dependent on comparables near it and days on the market as well as the sellers position.  You would be amazed how much you can negotiate if you have an eager seller.

 I would look at several houses that have all of the things you are looking for to get a feel for pricing.  This should give you an idea of what the market is for example, a 3 br house with garage, 2 ba etc.  Check out the neighborhoods in the day and at night.

Also do some research and think about what type of house you want.  Fixer upper....little bit of work needed or move in ready.  There are pro's and con's to both.

author: AutumnCelestial
body:
The gaming industry has become fairly sensationalist. People have already moved on from the Blitzchung incident and are already clamoring for the CoD BR mode. A lot of gamers are sheep.

This is coming from a vanilla wow player that's been in and out of the ATVI toxic relationship.

body: Something I would consider is how ppl who retained jobs throughout, now may be considering they need to level up their housing to more bedrooms to accommodate at homes offices. So instead of a 3br, they maybe need a 4 or 5 br house for home office if both or 1 adult will work from home. It's possible corporations will discover that having office spaces are expensive and in required in this day and age. Pushing ppl back to their homes, having them finance the "office space". Then again, we may all go back to the disease office and this wfh is all temp.

author: Timstertimster
body:
But this demand is artificial, because of privatization of basic needs. It’s a uniquely American folly to think that private enterprise would ever build infrastructures that benefit society. 

If highways were built by corporations, it would be completely unaffordable to build a business like amazon, because they would charge usage fees to ensure Amazon’s delivery profits get transferred to the highway builder. By the way, that’s exactly what’s happening with the internet now due to the removal of Net Neutrality laws. 

If healthcare was not private, prescription drugs would be more affordable because you wouldn’t have lobbies in Washington creating laws that prevent competition. Did you notice that it’s illegal to import drugs? Why isn’t it illegal to import engine parts then? Or soy beans?

Same with housing. If housing was a non profit business because a minimum amount of feelings would be built for people to live in, you could still be paying extra for a nicer home but you wouldn’t be forced to pay $4,000 for a 1-BR apartment just because you work in a densely populated area (Look up rentals in San Jose CA and you’ll know I’m not making this up).

As long as retiring generations finance their life style through stock market investment, we will have engineered inflation because without it there would be no growth.

author: j33tAy
body:
I rent a room now and sold my cars.

I used to spend $2.3kin rent for a 1 BR in Arlington/Falls Church area. I never spent any time there though. I used to put it up on airbnb when I would go out of town for $120/night.

I now pay $600/mo for a shared spot which is absurdly cheap around here. 

I also had a new Charger and used Corolla. Sold both a few years ago and bike/metro to commute.

At some point I got really upset about how I earned a lot of money but never really saved anything. I decided to basically live like a hobo for a few years, save, invest and YOLO.

It's paying off pretty well actually.

author: mrpoopistan
body:
There's an argument that right now the market isn't unduly fond of companies with more debt and less cash.

There are definitely folks who are preparing to ride the outbreak out for 18 months, and that's suggested in the response to certain companies and their debt and cash levels.

Looking through that filter . . . yeah, they're pretty different. Of the two, WDC is by far the more likely to die a horrible death due to rona.

FTR, I love companies with that sort of profile. I was into Altria, for example, heavy when the threat of mega lawsuits was there. Generally, if you have a proven market and major headwinds, I like you because headwinds aren't forever.

YMMV, obviously.

author: mrpoopistan
body:
Thx.

I've been birddogging the shorts and pretty much betting against them the last two weeks. Especially on otherwise good businesses.

Just trying to figure out exactly how committed to buy-and-hold I want to be.

FTR, I think we're mostly facing a V-shaped recovery, but I have certain western economies struggling to bounce back. I've mostly focused on companies with greater exposure in their supply chains to Asia. For example, I thought the beating Western Digital took was completely undeserved, and that bet is paying off handsomely.

As long as the U.S. doesn't trigger a debt crisis, I'm fairly optimistic.

author: BroskiMcDoogleheimer
body:
I bought my first option and am still wondering what to do with it. It's WDC Put 49 expiring tomorrow 3/13.

1) If I sell to close the contract I make $750 (or $559 profit after subtracting $191 contract cost)

2) Or I can exercise it and make $989 ($49-$39.11*100) or $798 profit after subtracting the $191 contract cost

So in this scenario exercising yields more profit - $798 vs $559. It's actually quite a big difference. So why do people always sell to close? I must be missing something.

author: ferociousturtle
body:
EQX-- very good management team. It's gotten hammered with the rest of gold, and is at a very good entry point right now.

STX-- it'll benefit from the exponential growth of data over the next decade, and has a better balance sheet than WDC. MU is approaching an attractive price point with the same bull thesis (data growth).

NUE-- well run US steel company, reasonable balance sheet, great long-term track record for management, dividends, etc. It's cyclical, and we may have a ways to go before the bottom, but we're probably closer to the bottom of its cycle than we are to the top.

HCC-- also in steel, it's a metallurgical coal company, which means it's much hated. Been following it for a while. The management seems solid, and it's at a deep discount.

I'm also looking at STMP and BKNG.
